Amines Plant No. 1 - U.S. Amines:

The plant is subject to and operated in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations and the EPA-RMP 

program.  The site maintains one PSM plan which includes application of the OSHA PSM rule and the EPA-RMP rule.  Amines Plant 

No. 1 includes the following RMP listed chemicals above the RMP threshold:

1.  Ammonia
2.  Isopropylamine
3.  Dimethylamine

Ammonia

Operations of the storage locations for ammonia and the operations using ammonia fall under the site PSM program.  Ammonia is 

stored as a liquefied gas.  There are three storage tanks for pure ammonia which do not have storage containment dikes 

because diking would not contain the ammonia from evaporation.  Storage for ammonia within the process unit does include 

diking as the ammonia stored in the process is not pure and diking would contain some of the material that would not 

immediately evaporate.  

Isopropylamine

Operations of the storage locations and production of isopropylamine fall under the site PSM program.  The storage locations 

are covered by automatic and/or manual fire suppression systems.  The storage areas are curbed or diked with hold-up volume 

adequate to contain all of the tank contents.

Dimethylamine

Dimethylamine is not manufactured but is received from another producer, stored, and resold.  The storage locations are 

covered by automatic and/or manual fire suppression systems.  The storage areas are diked with hold-up volume adequate to 

contain all of the tank contents.

The site PSM program also has policies that go beyond the OSHA PSM and EPA-RMP rules.  Some of those polices are listed 

below:

1.  Sight glass use: Sight glass use is discouraged in hazardous chemical service.  In cases where sight level indicators are 

needed, magnetically coupled, metal gauges are used or other provisions are made to protect against releases from breakage.
2.  Quarter-turn valves (1" size or less) are fitted with oval handles to reduce the risk of releases from bumping a straight 

handle valve open.
3.  Qualitative risk assessment is incorporated into our PHA and MOC process in order to provide more consistent evaluation 

of risk.  This provides better guidance in reducing risk, over the HAZOP only type of analysis.
4.  The plant belongs to and participates in a local emergency response group (LEPC) and a local community advisory panel 

(LCAP).
5.  All operators are trained and certified in the jobs they perform.
6.  All employees have the authority to shut down any process or stop any job, in order to maintain safe operation.
7.  A self-paced training program covers job specific tasks, principles of chemical engineering, safety, and regulatory 

issues.
8.  All plant operators are trained in emergency response.
9.  The plant has an extensive fire fighting system with monitor nozzles, hoses, foam generating capability and water 

reservoir.
10.  The plant has a portable emergency command vehicle complete with air monitoring equipment, radio and cellular phone 

systems, emergency response and decontamination materials.
11.  The plant alarm system is tested weekly.
12.  Emergency response personnel are trained in first aid and CPR.

propionitrile to prevent absorption of liquid or vapors into the skin.  The vapor space of the storage tank is purged with

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program Overview:

At US Amines, we are dedicated to being an industry leader in protecting the environment, the health, and safety of both our employees and the communities in which we operate.  Like our community neighbors, the people who work at the Bucks site want a clean, safe environment, with no illnesses or injuries at work, home, or play.  That is why US Amines has a "zero incident" goal.  We are committed to reducing emissions and continuously improving our performance toward zero injuries and zero environmental incidents.

The US Amines Bucks Plant participates in a local community advisory panel and works with other area industrial facilities to promote safety in our operations.  The LeMoyne Community Advisory Panel and the LeMoyne Industrial Park companies are recognized by local, state, and national organizations for outstanding cooperation.  This continued partnership ensures that the community where we all live and work will be a safe place now and in the future.

Our Facility:

We manufacture several different chemicals in the family of amines.  Our products are used to produce agricultural chemicals, water treatment chemicals, and drugs.  Our Isopropylamine is a chemical combination of isopropyl alcohol (the same chemical as in rubbing alcohol) and ammonia (the same chemical as in home floor cleaning products).  This is sold to other chemical manufacturers who make herbicides and agriculture products like popular home and farm product, RoundUp.  The chemicals that we handle and report on include the following RMP listed chemicals: Ammonia, Isopropylamine, Cyclohexylamine, Dimethylamine, and Propionitrile.  We also operate a fertilizer plant owned by IB Nitrogen, that is not covered by RMP.  We have about 45 site employees and 15 resident contractors.

Plant Safety Activities:

The plant has a site director (plant manager) who oversees all plant activities.  The staff includes an occupational safety manager, process safety manager, environmental man

ager, production engineers, and maintenance engineers.

All plant employees must attend at least one safety meeting per month.  Safety meetings include training on regulatory requirements and plant specific issues.  Testing is conducted in safety meetings to insure the information is understood.

Plant operators are members of the BEST team (the Bucks Emergency Services Team).  They are trained in the specifics of incident command, emergency response, and medical response.  The plant conducts weekly tests of the plant alarm system and conducts emergency response drills.

The US Amines Bucks plant complies with RMP and OSHA 1910.119, (the OSHA Process Safety Regulation) through our Process Safety Management Program.  The Bucks plant manages all plant processes per our Process Safety Management program.  The program meets all of the RMP and OSHA requirements such as:
*  Develop and implement a risk management system.
*  Conduct hazard assessments of all processes.
*  Implement accident prevention requirements.
*  Develop an emergency response program that is coordinated with local agencies.
*  Track and analyze incidents to prevent reoccurrence.

Plant 5-Year Accident History: 
RMP requires us to tell the public about accidents involving the listed chemicals that resulted in injuries or serious on-site or off-site impact.  Here is a summary:

Accident  2002   2003   2004   2005   2006   2007YTD 
RMP        0         0         0         0         0         0

How We Keep Our Plant Safe:

People: Our Most Valuable Safety Resource
1. All plant operators are trained and certified in the jobs they do.
2. All employees have the authority to shut down any process or stop any job, in order to maintain safe operation.
3. A self-paced training program covers job specific tasks, principles of chemical processing, safety, and regulatory issues.
 
Equipment: Maintained in Safe Condition
1. All plant process equipment is subjected to mechanical integrity inspections to look for cor

rosion or wear.
2. Safety devices such as pressure relief valves and shutdown systems are inspected and tested on a regular basis.
3. A thermographic camera allows us to check for temperature deviations in equipment, check for electrical faults, and verify levels.
4. Glass level gauges have been replaced with metal, magnetically-coupled gauges.

Safety Systems: Protective Safety Net
1. All storage tanks and process vessels are protected against over-pressure by safety relief valves, much like the safety relief valve on your home water heater.
2. Process safety systems are programmed in our process control computers.  If a designated level, pressure, temperature, or other parameter goes out of range, the process will shut down automatically.
3. Oxygen analyzers protect the integrity of key equipment including various boiler, compressor, and reactor operations.
4. All plant modifications and procedure changes undergo a management of change process that involves operations, maintenance, engineering, and management review.

Prepared: For Emergency Response
1. All plant operators are trained in emergency response, fire fighting, and must pass a physical agility test.
2. The plant has an extensive fire fighting system with monitor nozzles, hoses, foam generating capability, and water reservoir. 
3. The plant has a portable emergency command vehicle complete with air monitoring equipment, radio and cellular phone systems, emergency response, and decontamination materials.
4. The plant alarm system is tested weekly to ensure that employees know how to use it.
5. Emergency response personnel are trained in first aid and CPR.
